audio_caption: The clip begins with the melancholic strumming of a solo acoustic guitar, creating a sentimental and somber mood. Suddenly, a loud squeaking sound effect reminiscent of a mouse briefly interrupts the music before fading away.  A male speaker then starts talking, first revealing that actress Candace Cameron Bure had "finally revealed the truth about her husband" after 21 years of marriage. The speaker continues in a narrative tone, further revealing that Cameron Bure, and NHL player Valery Bure, have been married since 1996.  He suggests that their marriage appears perfect "with no affairs, no fights or temporary splits." The clip concludes with the speaker asking a rhetorical question about any marriage being "picture perfect, flawless".

The audio clip begins with a male speaker discussing Cameron Bure's early career. He mentions her role as D.J. Tanner on "Full House," her family background in acting, including her brother Kirk, and her later appearances on "Growing Pains". The speaker has a conversational, slightly analytical tone. He notes how Bure attended a charity hockey game featuring her "Full House" co-star Dave Coulier.

The audio clip features one male speaker who is narrating a story in an informative tone. He mentions introducing a woman to a "Russian hockey player, Valeri Bure" who would later become her husband and was a "big fan of Full House." The speaker further explains that the woman, Candace Bure, was nineteen, and her husband-to-be was twenty-one. The narrator details the couple's quick progression from their first date to their wedding.

The audio clip features a single male speaker providing narration, referencing a wedding and mentioning specific names like "John Stamos," "Bob Saget," and "Dave Coulier," suggesting he's discussing celebrities. The speaker uses an informative and enthusiastic tone. In the background, music plays, sounding light and celebratory, maybe fitting for a wedding, featuring strings and piano.

The audio clip begins with a single male speaker discussing marriages that fail due to incompatibility, contrasting this with the lasting relationship of Candace Cameron and Valery Bure. He notes that Valery once sent Dave Coulier a personalized hockey stick "Thanks for Candace" to honor his role in their meeting. He goes on to mention the couple having children: Natasha, Lev, and Maxim.

The audio begins with a discussion of Candace Cameron Bure's life, noting that she "became a Christian." Her brother, having converted earlier, gave her religious books which influenced her faith. The narrator adds that Bure took time to care for her children before returning to acting, listing her guest spot on "That's So Raven" and roles in Hallmark movies and "Make It or Break It." The passage ends with a note on the consistency of her marriage. The single speaker has a factual and informative tone.

The audio clip features a single male speaker with an informative tone, discussing the curiosity surrounding someone's marriage, especially within an industry "never really been associated with successful matrimony". He then summarizes that the person's view on marriage became clearer when they set out their "blueprint for wedded bliss" in a book about "juggling priorities and purpose". Finally, the speaker concludes that she attributed the longevity of her marriage to her "religious beliefs". Background music plays softly throughout the audio clip, providing a sense of gravity to the discussion.

The audio begins with a male speaker discussing Candace Bure's statement that her job was "to be submissive to her husband", and that this is the key to a healthy marriage. The speaker notes Bure wrote that her "husband is a natural-born leader", and that she finds a way to honor that. He then reports that she is "not a passive person", but chooses to fall into a "submissive role" in her relationship to make her marriage and family work. He goes on to mention that these remarks caused controversy, which led to Bure doing an interview with The Huffington Post. Throughout this, there is background music; a gentle classical piece, which adds a contemplative and neutral mood.

The clip starts with a solo female speaker, with a measured and explanatory tone, defining "submissive" in a biblical context as "meekness...strength under control...bridled strength", and how it should not be misunderstood as implying two authorities in a household. She notes that some people were unsatisfied by this explanation. The speaker then continues describing the previous speaker by saying that she elaborates by remarking, "I think they're thinking of it in terms of a perverted fifty shades of grey kind of definition". The tone remains explanatory, clarifying that this understanding is incorrect and that she and her spouse "want to honor God". She also mentions that a word has caused controversy that she did not anticipate.

The clip starts with a male narrator describing how someone's social media accounts went wild, particularly around an Instagram post showing off muscles with the caption "Nothing weak about this". He notes the varied comments to the post, including one person saying, "Being submissive isn't weak at all, it's biblical, good for you," and another countering, "I agree there's nothing weak or wrong about your life or marriage, but when you publicize it and sell it, I believe there is." The narrator notes the debate continued for over a year.

The audio clip begins with a single female speaker. The speaker states, "In January 2015 moreover, Bure gave an interview to Yahoo parenting to establish that she hadn't changed her views about these issues." Then, she continues to quote Bure stating "I put my husband on a pedestal so he can grow, and he does the same for me," and further paraphrases her views on marital roles. The tone is informative and neutral. The background contains an inaudible humming sound, and the speaker's statements trail off without a concluding sentence.

The clip begins with a narrator describing a discussion that took place on "The View" concerning the role of a leader in relationships, with Candace Bure's differing views. The narrator says Bure was outnumbered in her opinions, which they considered outdated. The narrator references Peter 3:1 and questions whether or not it has helped Bure and her husband. The tone throughout is informative and slightly conversational. The clip transitions to some light, acoustic guitar-based music with a gentle and reflective mood.

The audio clip begins with a male speaker discussing an event that occurred in June 2016, and quotes a message that someone named Bure posted on her 20th wedding anniversary. He then quotes, "Let's be real for a second", then refers to celebrating "20 years of marriage." He further quotes her in saying, "22 years together as a couple," and "I couldn't be more proud to be here and love my man the way I do, but let me assure you, it hasn't been all roses the whole journey." The speaker then asks, "Wait, what?" before quoting her again on several tough years, "ups and downs, bad attitudes and bad decisions," and that "we've persevered." The quote continues stating that "We rode them out. We loved each other through them" and "We kept the focus, God's glory," followed by "We're both better for it." The speaker then quotes, "I'm so grateful and thankful for the man I married. Neither of us are perfect, far from it and we'll continue to make mistakes because we're human." The speaker then states that "Some might have taken the Facebook post as a sign that the marriage was slowly disintegrating. But, given that all relationships hit their snags, that may not have been the case." He then notes that in March 2016, Bure revealed to InTouch that she and her husband "Still have an active love life" and that "When I'm home, we have to keep things alive."

The audio clip starts with a male speaker sharing positive news about Candace Cameron Bure's career, mentioning her 21-year marriage, Fuller House, her faith, and how it may have led to a happy marriage, ending with a call to action to share the video with friends, delivered in a celebratory tone. This speaking part fades into musical accompaniment that sounds like it would be from a church or gospel setting. The music's tone can be described as upbeat and joyful, with the primary instrument being the organ.
